fol.16r
May it please yo[r good L. I have nothing more to
signifie, for mine owne negotiation, till I heare from
yo
r
L. It might have steeded me muche for many
respectes, if untill
at her
Ma
tie
had fully resolved,
I might ether have knowen, by some litle intimation,
wherup
o
it hath staied, or had somew
at
said unto me,
to intertaine them heere
e while. For although I
have devised
e best
at I could, to answear their de-
maundes, yet I see they are not satisfied, and I am
alwaies uncertaine, howe well my answears may ac-
cord w
t
her Ma
ties
designes. It is signified
very nowe, by l
re
s from
e Campe,
at
e 5 of this
moneth, a part of
e Ravelin, where o
r
souldiers had
mined, and placed stoare of powder, was sette a fire
and blowen up, w
t
200 men in it: of w
ch
there were
very fewe saved, but were ether by
e mine, or by o
r
men after slaine, and many of them drowned in
e water
fast by. The Ravelin therupon was p
nt
ly assaulted
and taken by
e Scottes, whose quarter was nearest,
w
ch
is thought a great steppe to
e taking of
e towne.
And we hope in like maner to heare every houre, of some
special attempt to be given besides. For o
r
approches,
galleries, other mines, and workes, are brought so neere
unto
e rampers in 5 or 6 places, as they were
ready, it is thought, about 4 daies past, to give upon
e
towne in all those places at an instant: as in
e meane
season, having planted theire artillerie upon 9 or 10
beddes, in severall places,
ei shoote day and night and
kill very many. Co. Maurice, in going about
to viewe
e workes, was defended from a bullet, by
e
meanes of his target, of w
ch
a splinter brake out, and hurt
his page standing by. The wether heere for this
moneth hath bin exceeding wette and windie, w
ch
has
bin a great hindrance to
e advancing of o
r
workes;
fol.16v
It is thought
at otherwise, we might before this have ca-
ried
e towne. This benefit we have onely,
at
e ma-
rishes thereby are waxed very deepe, so as
e Enemie
hath no meanes to convey in any souldiers, w
ch
he did often
times before. There is a speeche,
at 400 of
Ver-
dugoes
souldiers are mutined, and have left him.
Ernestus
, we heare, doth assemble all his forces, for some
special purpose, w
ch
is unknowen yet heere, but onely by
conjecture, having sent already to
e castel of
Wo
adjoi-
ning to
Berghen
300 mariners, it is supposed he intendes
upon
e Ile of
Tertol
. It is advertised hither from
e Enemies contrey,
at
e
Co. Charles Mansfelt
is gone to
e Spawe, leaving most of his troupes between
Arras
and
Douay.
The bruite goeth heere,
at
e P. of Anholt,
is come to Co. Maurice, as
ei say but to see, and to salute
him. But by reason of a secret motion, w
ch
hath bin made
by frendes heeretofore, for a matche betweene
e Prince and
e
Lady Emilia de Nassau
Co. Maurices sister both by
father
and
mother,
it is supposed
at his comming is chiefly
for that. But for ought I can perceave, by talke w
t
those
at seeme to knowe it,
e Lady hath no fansie, to marie w
t
any Germane. There are appointed from hens,
to goe into Scotland to
e baptisme of
e
Prince
Mons
r
Brederode
e elder, and Mons
r
Valke of
Zelande.
For
at yo
r
L. may desire to see a plotte of this siege, I
endevoured long agoe, to sette one a worke, but it was
not possible, w
t
any safetie to
e workeman, to doe it w
t
any
perfitnesse, till o
r
artillerie was throughly planted. Nowe
e inclosed is sent unto me, w
ch
is done somewat sleightly
and in a smalle rowme, w
t
out any trimming, for
at
e party
doth promise to send me a larger, and exacter. Howbeit
he doth assure me,
at
e just distance between o
r
campe and
e towne,
e compasse of
e entrenchem
t
, and
e length of
e
towne, w
t
e forme of
e angels, portes and bulwarkes, together
w
t
e fortes, waters, waies, and suche other general thinges,
fol.17r
in
at sort as they present themselves towardes o
r
campe,
are sette downe in just proportion, according to
e scale
of passes joined to it, w
ch
is onely meant of ordinarie
going passes, accounting two foote to a passe. Although
it be no draught to content yo
r
L. yet for
at it is
e first
at I have yet seene, and is done by a skilfull person, who
sent it me hither in a ruder forme, I have caused it heere
to be somew
at
better drawen, and I send it heerew
t
.
And
thus for this p
nt
I take my humble leave.
From
e Hage July 10 1594.
Yo
r
L. most humbly bounden Tho. Bodley
